stream_context.summary: Kaze primarily focused on programming and fine-tuning the physics for a paper airplane object, which acts as a transport mechanic to a pyramid. This involved extensive trial-and-error with physics variables. He also implemented a star-giving Toad NPC, began animating a rubber band slingshot, and discussed his views on game design, streaming, and future projects.

development_findings.summary: The stream's main focus was programming a dynamic physics simulation for a paper airplane object, aiming for a swooping, semi-chaotic flight path rather than a simple linear one.
development_findings.quote: We want it to move like a real paper plane. We want it to go swoop, swoop, you know what I mean?

development_findings.summary: Kaze made a conscious decision to create a physics-based system for the paper plane instead of a simpler, pre-scripted animation path, preferring the challenge and feel of a simulated object.
development_findings.quote: Of course, I can just put it on a spline, but then I just have to add a spline and doing these computations, I prefer that. That's why there's some kind of physical basis for it.

development_findings.summary: The paper airplane mechanic serves to transport Mario to the top of a large pyramid in a level tentatively named 'Handmade Heights'.
Kaze noted a shift in performance limitations, stating the game is now primarily bottlenecked by the N64's Reality Signal Processor (RSP), which influences development choices.
development_findings.quote: my game now is RSP bottlenecked. So that's a thing to bring up.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is leveraging F3DX3, a newer and faster microcode, to improve performance, particularly for tasks bottlenecked by the RSP.
A bug was discovered where pressing the A button on the first frame after being launched from a cannon causes a crash, which Kaze noted seems to be present in the original Mario 64.
Kaze identified a visual glitch with offset textures as being an emulator-specific issue (Gliden64) and not present when running on actual N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: The offset textures are a Glidenbug. I can show you. It's gonna look fine on N64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a cardboard cutout Toad NPC, experimenting with dialogue generated by ChatGPT to make it sound more 'soulless' and 'mechanical' to fit the course's theme.
development_findings.quote: Visitor detected, dispensing star. Take it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that the quality standard for modern 3D platformers is so low that a game can become a fan favorite simply by not having major flaws, citing 'Battle for Bikini Bottom' as a key example.
context_findings.quote: I think the bar for 3D platformers is so incredibly low that making a 3D platformer is easy at this point... if you just make a hack or make a game that doesn't suck, I think it's going to be popular. That's my theory on the matter.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong disdain for what he perceives as making excuses, particularly when people claim they lack time for personal projects due to school or work commitments.
context_findings.quote: I've always been a hater for people that are like, oh, I can't work on my R64 because I have school. Bitch, school is like six hours a day. You still are awake for 10 hours a day beyond that. You have all the time you want and you're just being a pussy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a complex relationship with streaming; he enjoys it but often gets frustrated by repetitive or simplistic questions from the chat, admitting he sometimes feels bad for lashing out.
context_findings.quote: I do kind of really like streaming. It's just that sometimes I just can't deal with it, I think.

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokes that the stress of dealing with his Twitch chat during development is more taxing than the technical challenges of ROM hacking itself.
context_findings.quote: You know, I thought what made you insane when you rommake is like the rommaking itself. But no, it's Twitch chat like watching you rommake.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to develop his own original 3D platformer game using Unreal Engine 5 after completing Return to Yoshi's Island, considering it a 'practical' choice despite viewing most modern engines as 'bloated pieces of shit'.
Kaze believes current AI programming tools are incapable of handling the nuanced, trial-and-error physics programming required for his work.
context_findings.quote: AI is horrendous at programming at the moment. It's not going to be able to figure any of this out.

biobak.summary: Biobak, the graphics artist, joined the stream chat, but there was no discussion of his specific contributions during this session.
biobak.quote: Hello, Biobak. Welcome to programming this and getting annoyed by chat. What else is new?

zeina.summary: Kaze greeted Zeina on stream, acknowledging her presence while showcasing the newly functional paper airplane mechanic.
zeina.quote: Hello Zeina, what are you doing? We just did the paper airplane. Look at it.

zeina.summary: When struggling with a rubber band animation in Blender, Kaze noted that his role is to create a functional base, as he is not the project's primary animator.
zeina.quote: it's technically fine because I'm not the animator for this game anyway. Really, I just need a decent base so that we can make this work.

key_stories.title: The Physics of a Paper Plane
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent most of the stream programming the physics for a paper airplane. Instead of a simple path, he aimed for a complex, realistic 'swooping' motion by balancing numerous simulated forces. This involved a meticulous, iterative process of tweaking variables until the chaotic system produced a reliable and visually interesting result.
key_stories.challenge: To create a believable and functional flight path for a paper airplane that could transport Mario to a specific location. The plane needed to feel dynamic and slightly chaotic, not like a static object on a rail.
key_stories.process: Kaze engaged in a lengthy process of trial-and-error, repeatedly adjusting physics variables like velocity, gravity, pitch, and friction. He added and removed various 'fudge factors' to introduce instability, observed the results in-game, and then returned to the code, slowly converging on the desired behavior.
key_stories.outcome: After extensive tweaking, Kaze successfully created a flight path that swooped up, stalled, dove down, and pulled up again. He then fine-tuned the initial velocity and timing to make it land precisely on a pyramid, completing the gameplay mechanic.
key_stories.key_quote: This is just such a volatile, chaotic system. If you've ever shot a real paper airplane, you know exactly what I'm talking about.

open_questions.context: Kaze is creating placeholder animations and notes he is 'not the animator for this game.' He creates a 'decent base' for the rubber band animation for the actual animator (Zeina, his spouse) to refine.
questions: Could you describe the hand-off process between you and Zeina? How much detail do you put into a 'base' animation before she takes over?
How does your personal relationship impact the creative feedback loop? Does it make it easier to give and receive criticism on art and animation?
What are the technical constraints that Zeina needs to be aware of when creating animations for the N64 engine?

open_questions.context: Kaze expressed skepticism about the upcoming Analogue 3D console, theorizing that the company's reluctance to send him a review unit implies the product is flawed.
questions: Beyond just being sent a unit, what are your biggest technical hopes and fears for a modern FPGA-based N64 like the Analogue 3D?
As a developer who pushes the hardware, what specific features would make a console like that a 'must-have' for the N64 homebrew and hacking community?
You said you'd get the 'same result with just parallel N64'. What would the Analogue 3D have to do better than high-accuracy emulation to justify its price?

open_questions.topic: Transitioning from Hardware Limits to Modern Engines
open_questions.context: Kaze stated his next project will be a 3D platformer in Unreal Engine 5. He acknowledges the power but calls modern engines 'bloated pieces of shit'.
questions: What specific design philosophies learned from the N64's limitations will you carry over to a project in a modern engine like Unreal?
You mentioned the game is now 'RSP bottlenecked'. How has managing specific hardware bottlenecks on the N64 prepared you for optimizing in a modern engine?
When you call modern engines 'bloated', what specific 'bloat' do you plan to actively avoid in your own commercial game?

open_questions.context: The level 'Handmade Heights' is shown to have multiple distinct biomes (desert, styrofoam mountains, castle). Kaze also programmed an NPC to be intentionally 'soulless' and 'mechanical'.
questions: What is the core theme or narrative that ties the different biomes of 'Handmade Heights' together?
How did the 'handmade' or 'arts-and-crafts' theme influence the decision to make the Toad NPC sound 'mechanical'?
How do you and Biobak collaborate to ensure visual and thematic consistency across such varied biomes within a single course?
